title: Will an Uber self-driving car with a member of the public as a passenger be involved in an auto accident while driving autonomously between 14 October 2016 and 1 January 2017?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Down to 0 on close-to-zero time left

http://www.autoworldnews.com/articles/25027/20161228/uber-self-driving-car-tests-deemed-illegal-volvo-anything-unlawful.htm In San Francisco, Uber argued that the Volvo cars being tested each had a driver inside who could do something if a problem were to arise that required human intervention. Because of this, Uber believed that it was not violating any laws, as the tested cars were technically not driverless, or at least not fully.  This would also have meant that GJO may have deemed any accident in SF as not qualifying as the vehicle was not "driving autonomously". Meanwhile, in Pittsburg, Uber is not required to report accidents.  http://www.ocregister.com/articles/last-739542-complete-streets.html
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Running out of time and adjusting down to reflect the falling probability of an accident.

Uber has self-driving cars in Pittsburgh. They've, however, removed the self-driving cars from California/San Francisco area. During this time frame, in Pittsburgh, snow should be expected. Additionally, I am putting in my prediction way past the Oct 14 start date knowing that there haven't been any accidents to date. I believe that there is still a chance of an accident occurring in Pittsburgh due to weather conditions that make the roads poor for driving.

http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/west/2016/12/19/435910.htm Uber self-driving vehicles in SF were reported running red lights and making dangerous turns across bike lanes.  
However, because they were operating without the kind of permit which requires them to report all incidents, these events were not reported.
Pressure was brought to bear by the City on Uber to get the proper permits or remove their cars.
After several days of arguing with City Hall, Uber has pulled its self-driving vehicles off the streets.
Thus, it's not likely that there will be an accident before the end of the year.
No,  number of self driving cars are too less for such accident to happen.
Beyond the (low) likelihood of mistakes that self-driving cars are yet to make, minor no-fault (that is, not Uber's fault) accidents are virtually unavoidable in the long run
Less time for an accident to happen.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The California order to Uber to stop its SF pilot and the relTed reporting on that made me realize that even if there is an actual accident Meeting the GJ Project criteria, we may never know about. According to a Forbes story about the California order, "Along with registering with the state, companies that receive California test permits must provide accident data on their vehicles, as well as details on how often autonomous drive mode is disengaged. By not having a permit, Uber wouldn’t have to provide that data, which the California DMV posts on its public web site."  Given that Uber has still not reported the results of its "investigation" of the late October accident in Pittsburgh, I have now concluded that Uber will only admit to accidents that are serious enough that it cannot deny them. I suspect that Uber's reluctance to obtain the $150 permit that California is demanding due to multiple factors, including a philosophical resistance to overregulation but also a preference to retain some optionality with respect to accident reporting. I don't know much about the Pittsburgh situation, which is the one where the greatest current accident exposure exists, but I have heard that Uber chose Pittsburgh in part because the local authorities were more accommodating than others. If so, and that idea  is supported by the lack of clarity over that late October accident, then I suspect we will not know soon whether or not an accident has occurred in Pittsburgh within the GJ prescribed period. That's not to say that the odds of a accident are zero, but I think the odds of our learning about it are zero!

http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-google-waymo-self-driving-20161213-story.html "Google began working on its self-driving technology in 2009 . . . . . Since then, its fleet of cars has covered more than 2.3 million miles in the San Francisco Bay Area, Austin, Arizona and Washington state. In their travels, the self-driving vehicles have been involved in 35 traffic accidents. Google has said its self-driving vehicles were at fault in only one collision.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  2.3m miles, 35 accidents, only one at fault.  Reported.

In the last few days there's been numerous reports of Uber taxis running red lights in SF; this represents smoke, but is there fire? This question asks if there will be an accident, not illegal or dangerous driving.  So, at this point, there isn't fire. Running red lights is extremely dangerous; if this continues, it's just a matter of time before there will be an accident.  So, there could be fire soon. The question requires that the vehicle be driving autonomously at the time of the accident; this may be something difficult to discern.  Uber may seek to shift all blame onto human drivers, or may pressure those involved to not file an accident report.  No report = no accident.  (Based on GJO failure to close this question when there was a report of an incident in Pittsburgh.) It's hard to access these variables, but I no longer think a zero forecast is safe, even though I continue to be of the opinion that there's way too many people invested in preventing (or failing to investigate) reports of accidents.

Doesn't increase my estimate, but makes me feel a little bit better about being so far above from the GJO consensus: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/dec/14/uber-self-driving-cars-run-red-lights-san-francisco
All calculations aside, I'm actually wondering if Ubers are ever simultaneously in 1) self-driving mode and 2) with a passenger. It seems like not really. Down to 1%.

I had been planning to reduce my probability estimate to 2% due to the further passage of time. However, I have delayed doing so for a few reasons: 1) the first of the Volvos expected to be deployed by year-end have now started to appear in Pittsburgh (faster than I expected); 2) a "handful" of Volvos have appeared in San Francisco as part of a similar pilot there; and 3) there was an October 18 incident in Pittsburgh in which an Uber "driverless" vehicle was reportedly rear-ended...Uber is "investigating". Regarding the latter, it is not clear if  public passenger was in the car or not. Note that there IS a potential problem in correctly resolving the final answer to this forecast question, as Uber MIGHT NOT reveal the actual accident statistics.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Based on 2014 PA highway statistics, the accident rate is about 1.23 per 1 million miles drive.  Excluding human error, the rate drops to about 1 per 4 million miles drive. Considering that, there are not many uber driverless cars running, and it will not be very likely that they will get a lot of millage. More importantly, based on articles of NY times and business insiders, uber doesn't have true autonomous cars, the safety drivers take over the car very often, this makes an accident almost entirely impossible.
@RiskStrategist: Passage of time, human driver, low passenger rates, and other drivers being aware.

This is not really a self-driving car, which by itself would have the accident rate of a teenage driver, but instead has the characteristics of the human driver supervising the driving. I assume that those supervisors are in their 30s and as such have an annual accident rate of about 5%. (I am assuming an equal mix of males and females.) I don't believe that the self-driving technology offers any improvement over the human supervisors, and indeed the humans are improving the self-driving performance. The evaluation period is 79 days, or .2164 of a year, so I adjusted the accident rate for that. I further adjusted for the fact that only 30% of the evaluation period remains as of today (12/8/16). I assumed that a public passenger will be in the car only 1/2 the time. Finally, I accounted for 14 Ford Fusions being on the road as part of this test for the full period, and added 1 full-period equivalent for the Volvos that are supposed to be introduced by the end of the year. (I don't think they will arrive much before the very end of the year, hence my estimate of only 1 full-period equivalent.) Finally, I assumed that there is a 5% chance that there has already been an accident not yet reported in the press, accounting for this by multiplying my a priori estimate of the probability of an accident in the already elapsed period by 5%.
Recent articles sound like very few passengers have actually been in autonomous Ubers, so revising my forecast down a lot.
It is very unlikely that this will happen with a human driver not driving but at hand
- There's a lot of resistance when it comes to fully autonomous vehicles. However, assisted driving can be incorporated without much effort.
Passage of time and difficulty in establishing a "Yes" as a resolution.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Only a month left till Jan 2017.

Updating the odds based on my earlier inability to comprehend the question. According to car insurance industry estimates that average driver can expect to be in an accident once every 17.9 years. or once every 214.8 months. With 2 months remaining that would be 1month / 214.8 months = .46% chance of an accident for an average driver. Assuming the Uber car carries a passenger 5x as often as an average driver in on the road gives 2.3%. I will double this and on the assumption that there is a high probably that the autonomous Uber car still has some bugs and call it 4.6%. I am having a difficult time finding the total number of Uber self-driving cars on the road, it is always described as a "small number". I will guess five Uber self-driving cars. [(1.046)^5]-1=25%
Another day gone, another 10,000 miles less opportunity for Uber to get in an accident.
This is simply a routine update reflecting the decrease in the amount of time available for an Autonomous Uber to get in a crash.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Bringing down as there's less time left in the year.
Getting down on time elapsed and news that drivers-engenders seem to be heavily engaged
Taking down due to passage of time
Low but but impossible. Unlikely to be at fault
As time lapses, exposure to accident is lower. Typical actuarial methods.

Downgrading from my previous forecast, based on these reasons: 1) It seems that these cars operate a great part of the time non-automously; 2) They seem to be another part of the time non-operative due to technical glitches.

This is a pure odds play. There are approximately 10 fatalities per 100,000 population per year in the US. Pittsburgh has a population of 300,000. There will be approximately 30 deaths in Pittsburgh from residents. There are probably another 200,000 people commuting to and in Pittsburgh per day for whatever reason. I will predict approximately 50 deaths in Pittsburgh out of 500,000 people. This is a .01% percent chance of death. This question is not even for the full year(Oct to Jan). Additionally, these cars do have a driver and an engineer in the front seat just in case. Additionally, the back seat is far safer than the front seat. The question states that a member of the public (who will be seated in the back) of an Uber vehicle to have a fatality. I say slim odds here. I put the odds at less than 1% even if the technology is horrible. I also predict that the technology continues to improve through 1 Jan 2017.
The technology is far from mature and the exposition is high. The urban traffic scenario is very complex and is hard for the technology cope well with all situations.

Autonomous cars are much safer. Also I've heard the Uber cars have a human driver in the autonomous vehicle to take control wherever necessary. So an accident is almost impossible to happen. Even a small one has a tiny chance of happening
This probability should degrade as the amount of time left for an accident declines. This is a routine update to reflect that fact.

It seems like this might have happened already. According to http://www.wtae.com/article/self-driving-uber-involved-in-collision-downtown/8059178 there was a collision between a self-driving Uber vehicle and another car on October 19. However, it's not clear whether the car was driving autonomously at the time so I don't know whether this definitely counts - I'm assuming not. Borrowing heavily from AABoyles' excellent logic, but with some modifications:
- It sounds like Volvo will deliver 100 cars by the end of 2016, and then Uber will have to outfit the cars with their autonomous technology. I'm not sure how long this takes but I would guess that not all 100 cars will be on the road by the end of 2016. Let's say they have 50 on the road by the end of the year. (http://www.theverge.com/2016/8/18/12541672/uber-volvo-partnership-autonomous-self-driving-car)
- An average Uber driver earns around $30 per hour in Pittsburgh, which I think equates to around 15-20 miles driven per hour. Assume that these cars are in use for 12 hours a day, then that's about 200 miles a day. 
- It sounds like the engineers in the car take over the driving fairly regularly - maybe every few minutes (this is as of August - it might be less frequent now). Plus, the cars only operate in a limited area in Pittsburgh that Uber have mapped very thoroughly. 
- Also, traffic is likely to move more slowly in the areas where these cars operate, so let's say that they travel around 100 miles a day under autonomous control.
- Assume an average of around 40 cars on the road between now and the end of December, that's 4,000 miles a day. There's 39 days left in the month, so that's 156,000 miles to be driven between now and the end of the year.
- Accidents in the US happen somewhere between every 160,000 miles and every 500,000 miles - it's probably more often in a city like Pittsburgh.
- So let's assume that the cars will drive another 160,000 miles by the end of the year, and accidents happen in Pittsburgh every 160,000 miles.
- To work out the probability I think we use the Poisson distribution - if my stats haven't failed me, then I think the probability of at least one accident before the end of the year is around 63%.
- This feels a bit high as I think Uber will be doing a lot to try to avoid having an accident and the associated bad press - e.g. maybe the operators in the car will take over if there's a potential accident, so maybe they will be a lot more likely to be in control at the time of an accident. I'll bring the probability down by a totally arbitrary 15% to 48%.

I needed to make a lot of assumptions, so let me list them explicitly:
0. Uber would only deploy them if they believed that the cars were approximately as safe as human drivers (so we can estimate using statistics based on human traffic). This is reinforced by the presence of a human driver, prepared to override the system if necessary.
1. There are going to be 100 vehicles in Uber's autonomous fleet by year's end. We don't know how many cars Uber has or will successfully deliver, but a better assumption is that they're on schedule and delivering linearly, indicating that half of the car*miles in the whole fleet assumption actually get driven.
2. 1. It seems like Uber drivers in metropolitan areas (like Pittsburgh, home of Uber's autonomous fleet) travel around 100 miles per 8 hr. shift. That said, I don't know how long they're on the road daily--could be as much as 24hr.
3. If all of them were on the road today, and all of them did 24 hour shifts, then there'd be 100 Cars * 300 miles / car*day * 41 car*days = 1,230,000 car*miles. My best guess is that the actual number is 50 cars * 100 miles / car*day * 41 car*days = 105,000 car*miles to be driven by year's end.
4. I can't find a great estimate for the ratio of accidents to miles driven, but an adequate one seems to be around 1 accident per 100,000 car*miles. Accordingly, the expected number of accidents is around 1 accident. This probability should degrade approximately linearly. Accordingly, for convenience sake, I'm pegging it at 41% today (with 41 days remaining in the year), though my true belief is closer to 50%.

I might be the outlier here but here are a few data points I am basing this on - 1. We are getting into the winter season (now this can go both ways, Uber might shut down the program during snow days, but if they don't I can see more chances of an accident). They've already said that bridges are a problem for them.
2. They just added another 100 new cars. So we are going from 4 to 104 cars. Which will increase the chance of an accident. There have a been at least 1 incident reported so far.
3. They seem to have rushed into this for PR reasons and that always means taking shortcuts and higher possibility of error. If this was Google, I'd give them a much lower probability of an accident. That being said, looking at everyone else giving such a low chance to this event happening, it does affect my rating and makes me want to go much lower (there should be a way for people to not see other forecasts as it causes bias).
Revising down 4% for passage of time.

Droping down from 63 % due to possibility that Uber might want to cover up any incidents officially. Still the fact that it hasn't happened doesn't mean it won't happen. New tech always comes with glitches they iron out during testing.

From my last forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/365412) I have lowered the number of days to 30, probability of no accident on auto pilot with passenger is 85%, so the accident rate is 15%, with 55% of reporting rate, the accident rate that could lead to a yes resolution would be around 8%. I have read somewhere (could not find link anymore, from some attorney site, but the original data is from Penn DOT) Thanksgiving and Christmas time are times with high accident rate, if Uber dares to keep the cars out, this could have a higher than usual risk of getting into an accident.

I am taking a mid-point of 50, not knowing the exact cadence of delivery. Bumping up the estimate to 12% based on the same calculation as earlier but with a larger pool of vehicles.

Implied accidents in Pittsburgh during forecast window: 298
Passenger car accidents % total: 56.1%; 167 passenger car accidents in forecast window.
Non-adverse condition accidents: 78.7% (adverse conditions would not be driving autonomously) - 131 non-adverse condition passenger car accidents in forecast window. Less bridge related accidents (uber auto cant do bridges) - 130 Seasonal adjustment: 140.4; Adjusted for non-alcohol related: (91.1%) - 127.9
Uber cars in Pittsburgh: 100; Total cars in Pittsburgh: 11,974,651. Uber share of total traffic: 0.00001
Unadjusted for concentration bias and non-bridge manual override, Uber's share of accidents should be 0, to the nearest vehicle.

225 Million Cars in the U.S.A.
5.7 Million accidents.  Likelihood of accident per car is 2.49% in one year i.e. 0.32% for the remainder of 2016 (as of November 14th). Uber has a Safety driver along with the car and they have an test program running in Pittsburgh: https://newsroom.uber.com/pittsburgh-self-driving-uber/ I don't know the number of test cards but 20 sounds reasonable. If so, the likelihood is 20*0.32 = 6.4% for a human drivers. Assuming that self-driving car along with a safety driver is safer at about 25% - the likelihood of an accident comes down to 4.8%. I am submitting 5% as my answer.

Looking at Google Data, it seems that their self driving cars are involved in about 1 incident per 1 million miles driven. Uber is much worse at disclosing this information. Given the constraints and limited number of miles driven, the event is highly unlikely.

https://techcrunch.com/2016/09/14/1386711/
As an enigneer is sitting in the driver's seat the chances for an accident should not be much higher than usually.
Chances for a car to be involved in an accident are around 4% per year (number of cars divided by accidents registred by the Police, very small accidents included). 
Chances per month: 0,3% (4% divided by 12).
So for one car the chance for an accident within the last remaining 2 month of 2016 is 0,6%
For 14 cars it is 8,4%
'Member of the public' is not an Uber employee. There won't be any members of the public in these cars, just Uber employees.

I believe that it is rather likely that some car, including a self-driving car, will be involved in an accident that is NOT its fault. For a better estimate, one would need look up the number of the cats running in this period.  The 70% guess is based on the assumption that there are several hundred such cars, and that they're running in typical urban environment.

I wanted to wait for more news but not much is forthcoming, so I am having some doubt that even if there is a crash, there may not be enough evidence to prove it.  My view of Uber entering the pilot with passenger (that could always pilot without them) is to generate goodwill, so in view of new accidents, the risk is high that the tide could turn against them, but they could also have a pilot without the passenger, and I think the utilization rate is going to go down.  On the other hand, Uber is pretty entrepreneurial and like to go in a market and make its own rules before the government makes those rules, which in the case in Penn, the two self driving car bills are pending (http://www.ncsl.org/research/transportation/autonomous-vehicles-legislation.aspx).  I think they are running out of time, so they might still have passengers in their safest routes to make their argument.  My computation thus: 50 cars
30 mph
15 hours per day
50 days to 40 days (reflects the change in time from my earlier forecast)
utilization rate 50% to 20% (cutting back on passenger as to not derail the pilot even if there were accidents)
60% auto mode rate
55% reporting rate (NHTSA report from 2010, reflecting the reporting rate of accidents which I thought was not necessary) You get 59,400 total miles, using the same formula (1-1/500,000)^59,400, the chance of no crash is 89%, the chance of crashing is around 11%. Edit: The math is wrong again, the 55% reporting rate should not be used to modify mileage, but instead on the chance of crashing.  The total mileage with reporting rate is 108,000 miles, then we plug it like this (1-1/500,000)^108,000, to get around 81% of no crash, the chance of crashing is around 19%,  55% of 19% is around 10% instead, so similar to the earlier result anyways.

These cars have a terrific safety record.  Assume 200 self driving cars in Pittsburg and other cities.  After crunching the data, Schoettle and Sivak concluded there's an average of 9.1 crashes involving self-driving vehicles per million miles traveled. One million over 200 cars is 50,000 miles per car. We have roughly 60 days until January. Each car probably drives 100 miles a day, for a total of 20,000 miles a day. That means it will take 50 days before we reach a million miles and an average of 9 crashes.  Putting my guess at 72% to account for improvements in car technology.

My base rates are from NHTSA data from 2015
https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/812318 To solve how many miles driven for a crash, I use 2015 crash is 6,296,000, mileage 31,000*10^8 driven estimated from fatality 35,092 / 1.12 fatality per 100million VMT (Vehicle Mileage Traveled).  You get around 1 crash per 500K Miles. For miles driven by Uber autopilot, I get around 50 cars (Google has about 58 as of Sep 2016), 
https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/www.g.u.00rz.com/en/us/selfdrivingcar/files/reports/report-0916.pdf Speed is around 25-30MPH, while sometimes go above, let's try 30MPH
https://www.wired.com/2016/09/heres-like-ride-ubers-self-driving-car/ It works from 7am to 10pm, so 15 hours per day
http://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/uber-pittsburgh-robo-taxi-experiment/ There is still about 70 days left until 2017, but if it's not safe to drive for normal cars (say snowing), it will not be on autopilot, so say 50 days I use 50% as utilization rate from a NBER paper, it is comparable to New York and Boston (hours driven, not miles driven)
http://www.nber.org/papers/w22083.pdf Auto mode rate is at around 60%, see the Google paper (62%) and the Digital Trend article (at least 30% manual) earlier.  The same Google paper mentioned that around 55% collisions are not reported, but as can be seen, Google is required to do monthly report (due to state law?), I am not sure if the same applies to Penn, but I will assume honesty from Uber. When you multiply everything together, you get around 337K = 50 cars * 30MPH * 15hr/day * 50 day * utilization rate 50% * autopilot rate 60%.  By dividing 337K/500K, you get around 0.67 crash.  A bit high to be honest, and you can tweak the scenarios (say 30 cars instead of 50, or the national rate could go over 500K, say 650K) to get a lower number, the rate would be down to 0.31 crash if both car and per crash mileage goes up.  Other things to consider is that the driver usually disengages auto before the accident.  On the other hand, the subject is so new that people may under/over estimate, so it pays to be contrarian. Edited: instead of simply do 337K/500K, try the probability equation setting P as the chance of crash, estimate at 1/500,000 miles, so you have not crashing 1-P = 1 - 1/500,000, do this 337,000 times, you get (1-1/500,000)^337,000, this is around 51%, so crash is around 49% instead.  Given the toss up of the situation, I am not changing it for now. The Google reports summarized up to Apr 2016 can be found here, also check on the May 2015 report, which summarizes all incidents up to that point, basically 1 per year since 2012 (the data started at 2010), while 2015 reported 3 incidences at auto mode by May.
https://google-self-driving-car-incidents.silk.co/
http://static.googleusercontent.com/media/www.google.com/en//selfdrivingcar/files/reports/report-0515.pdf

Uber has yet to have a crash caused by the self-driving technology. Still, as ridership increases in the next few months, there could always be a possibility that a crash occurs (it has happened with Google already). Another factor consider is that Pittsburgh is a very hilly city with a lot of narrow streets

This question does not have a very long time frame, so it is pretty unlikely that there will be an accident, while over a longer time frame it would be fairly likely.  While self driving cars have been shown to more safe than human driven cars, the basic fact is that the more they drive, the more likely they are to be involved in an accident. Rate of accidents:
This article: http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/28/nyregion/that-wild-taxi-ride-is-safer-than-you-think-a-study-says.html indicates that the accident rate for black cars is 3.7 per million miles driven in manhattan.  I would imagine that accidents might be less common in Pittsburgh, and while black car drivers are probably generally very good, a self driving car will probably be even more safe since a human driver still has a base level of distraction, so I'll put the rate for Uber's cars at about 1 per million miles driven. Volume of driving:
I'm not sure how many cars are in the pilot program, I saw something about having 16 self-driving cars somewhere.  This website provides data on the average driving speed in various cities, and while it doesn't include Pittsburgh, similar sized cities average somewhere around 20-30 mph.  I'm going to make a rough estimate that with about 10 cars each driving about 25 hours a week at an average of 20 mph, Uber's self driving cars will be totalling about 5000 miles per week.  Over 10 weeks this adds up to 50,000 miles. My estimate uses a Poisson distribution with an average rate of p = 50,000/1,000,000 = 0.05.  The probability of zero crashes occurring during this period is then 95% (The probability of zero events is roughly (1-p) for small values of p), so the probability of 1 or more is 5% .  There is quite a bit of variance to this estimate.  Doubling or halving the amount of driving or the accident rate will roughly double or half the probability, and there is a a lot of leeway in my guesses.

While there are few self-driving Uber cars on the road, the fact is that fender-benders are a relatively common phenomenon (even when not caused by the driver, or in this case the lack thereof). My own belief is that the heightened defensive driving capabilities of the self-driving cars will reduce the accident rate somewhat, but it is still by no means a sure thing that the entire fleet will make it 2.5 months without a single collision, major or minor.

the key here is "while driving autonomously." the driver is still able to control the car, and in any computer-unrecognized situation it drops control to the driver. given basic human nature my guess is any accident will result from driver error or the driver wresting control in a quasi-dangerous situation. given a) the small number of self-driving cars b) the probability that driver error will be the cause in any accident and c) the short time frame, odds seem low.  But a clarification is in order: if the driver takes control right before a collision and fails to avoid it, is the answer to this question "yes?" Makes a big difference. Can admins respond??

I don't think so.  Tesla has had self driving for a while and only one crash. The technology that self driving cars are using is all relatively similar and well understood methods. Specifically with Uber they have A LOT more equipment attached then Tesla because there is no consumer so in that regard Uber has an advantage when it comes to sensor data quality and quantity.  Also there are not many of them roaming around yet and there probably won't be many people trying them out when you are comparing it to normal uber uses or even tesla autopilot miles. So I think for that reason the likelihood of an accident would be low, mainly because the technology hasn't proven faulty yet and its fairly well understood and also just because of statistical reasons. Total number of uber cars being tested in Pittsburgh is up to 100. Started in mid September. Believe will ramp up to 100 by end of year. Assuming linear increase, then as of 17 Oct would expect c. 35 cars to be on the road. Average number on road between now and end of year would be c. 70. National statistics for US imply c. 1 crash in every 50 cars over the course of a year, or c. 2% chance. This implies that the probability of crashing in a 1.25 month period (the average time from between now to the end of year ... because I will be using the average number of cars) is 2% * 1.25/12 = 0.2% Probability of any car crashing is equal to 1 - (probability of no cars crashing). Probability of 70 (average) cars not crashing is (1-0.2%)^70 = 99.8%^70 = 86%. Therefore the probability of at least one car crashing is 14%. However, question requires a crash to happen with a passenger in it. So need to bring in utilisation rate - articles state that in LA the utilisation rate is 64%. Assume same for Pittsburgh. Therefore need to adjust the percentage to 14% * 64% = 9%

it seems Uber has had an accident before this question was posted.  More interestingly it seems Uber is confining its test to a specific geographic area, has two drivers and limits itself to specific driving conditions.  If I was an Uber AV program manager I would have had a young go getter data mine all the vehicle accidents in Pittsburg.  I then would plot maps or safe routes for Uber cars to drive where no or very few accidents occurred.  That means I would also plot times of accidents and weather conditions...etc..etc.  Uber AV cars probably drive the safest routes in the city, only in daylight during time periods when few if any accidents occur.   If an Uber AV accident happens the fallout will be consequential.  The main goal for Uber from a strategic perspective is prove you can do this safely!   Not how many miles or passengers logged.  If Uber can do it safely all the other metrics are icing on the cake.  To what extreme will Uber take safe driving?   "Uber has acknowledged a fender-bender involving one of its four autonomous Ford Fusions....There has also been one citizen report of an autonomous Uber driving the wrong way down a one-way street...Admittedly, the program is small in scope. It's confined to a particular area of town, limited to certain driving conditions, and requires two front-seat passengers in each vehicle, one of whom can take control at a moment's notice. Given those restrictions, maybe it's not surprising that the program hasn't seen more accidents.   http://www.csmonitor.com/Business/In-Gear/2016/1009/How-are-Uber-s-self-driving-cars-doing-in-Pittsburgh

There will be a safety-driver in each self-driving Uber who will be able to take control of the Uber in any situation, making it very unlikely that an S-D Uber increases the likelihood of causing an accident. Very few S-D Ubers will be available and the chances of any one driver being involved in a car accident are already low for a 4-month period (10 million accidents a year for 200-230 million drivers). While this would put the probability at less than 1%, the small chance that there is either a design-flaw in the driverless tech or perhaps a fame-seeking saboteur increase my prediction. Also, at this time, I think Pittsburg will be the testing ground, which has tricky late fall and early winter weather. Even then, Uber's will probably limit if not prohibit operating in bad weather.
